posts.name: Ray Flanagan
posts.cooked: What can be shared over robot WiFi? Are there limits on data amounts? Is it secure? I’m thinking of creating a utility app for practices and collaboration that would use the robot WiFi. I’m curious if this would even be possible.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: R704 has many of the details that you seek.

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked:
The text has been cleaned up to enhance readability and clarity while preserving the original meaning. Here is the revised version:

Not entirely sure what you're asking, but what access point setup do you have? It depends heavily on how your practice field is configured—whether you're using a single VH-109 in 2.4 GHz AP mode, a second AP operating at 6 GHz, or if you have additional switches involved. Additionally, what are you trying to achieve? This will help provide clearer guidance for your query.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked: See R704. Only use allowed ports and bandwidth to communicate with the ROBOT. Communication between the ROBOT and the OPERATOR CONSOLE may not exceed the following and is restricted to network ports listed in Table... For practice, the bandwidth limit and firewall can be disabled.

posts.name: Ray Flanagan
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text, formatted as requested:

Sorry, I wasn’t very clear in my initial inquiry. I aim to develop a utility application, akin to AdvantageKit or Pathplanner, designed for teams to utilize. This platform will facilitate activities such as connecting wirelessly during construction periods or off-seasons, allowing multiple students to link up.

posts.name: Sam Weaver
posts.cooked: Connecting multiple students to the same robot network wirelessly cannot happen during an event. Cannot connect directly either. Once you’ve joined an event and activated your radio device, it will only connect to the field, not your phone or laptop.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: NC Technical Volunteer, FRC4534 Alumni, FRC435 Mentor

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: I'd recommend starting with NetworkTables for device-robot communication. They offer an easy setup with various client libraries available, though some perform better than others.
